sen.j: 崇神天皇（すじんてんのう、開化天皇10年（紀元前148年） - 崇神天皇68年12月5日 (旧暦)（紀元前29年1月9日）は、『古事記』『日本書紀』に記される第10代の天皇（在位：崇神天皇元年1月13日 (旧暦)（紀元前97年2月17日） - 同68年12月5日 (旧暦)（紀元前29年1月9日））。
sen.e: Emperor Sujin (148BC - 9th January 29BC) was the 10th emperor of Japan (reigned from 17th February 97BC to 9th January 29 BC) recorded in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihon Shoki" (The Chronicles of Japan).

Emperor Sujin (148BC - 9th January 29BC) was the 10th emperor of Japan (reigned from 17th February 97BC to 9th January 29 BC) recorded in the Kojiki (The Records of Ancient Matters) and the Nihon Shoki (The Chronicles of Japan).

Emperor Sujin (148 B.C. - January 9, 29 B.C.) was the tenth emperor of Japan (reigned from February 17, 97 B.C. to January 9, 29 B.C.) recorded in "Kojiki" (The Records of Ancient Matters) and "Nihon Shoki" (The Chronicles of Japan).
sen.cmt: B.C.としました。日付の表現を修正しました。

sen.j: 和風諡号は『紀』では御間城入彦五十瓊殖天皇（みまきいりびこいにえのすめらのみこと）。
sen.e: "Nihon Shoki" records that he was posthumously given the name Mimakiiribikoinie no Sumera no Mikoto.
The Nihon Shoki records that he was posthumously given the name Mimakiiribikoinie no Sumera no Mikoto.
The Nihon Shoki records that he was posthumously given the name Mimakiiribikoinie no Sumera no Mikoto.

sen.j: また、御肇國天皇（はつくにしらすすめらみこと）と称えられる。
sen.e: He is also known as Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto.
He is also known as Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto.
He is also known as Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto.

sen.j: 『記』では御真木入日子印恵命（みまきいりひこいにえ）である。
sen.e: "Kojiki" records him as Mimakiirihikoinie.
The Kojiki names him as Mimakiirihikoinie.
The Kojiki names him as Mimakiirihikoinie.

sen.j: 現代の日本の学術上、実在の可能性がある程度見込める初めての天皇である。
sen.e: He is the first Japanese emperor that many modern scholars agree might have actually existed.
He is the first Japanese emperor that many modern scholars agree might have actually existed.
He is the first Japanese emperor that many modern scholars agree might have actually existed.

sen.j: 人物
sen.e: Personal profile

sen.j: 記紀に伝えられる事績の史実性、欠史八代に繋がる系譜記事等には疑問もあるが、3世紀から4世紀初めにかけて実在した大王 (ヤマト王権)と捉える見方が未だ少なくない。
sen.e: There are doubts regarding the historical validity of his exploits recorded in "Kojiki" and "Nihon Shoki" as well as genealogical accounts of his connection to the Kesshi Hachidai (eight undocumented emperors) but there are still many who consider him to be the king (Yamato Sovereignty) who lived from the 3rd century to the beginning of the 4th century.

There are doubts regarding the historical validity of his exploits recorded in the Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki as well as genealogical accounts of his connection to the Kesshi Hachidai (eight undocumented emperors); however, there are still many who consider him to be the king (Yamato Sovereignty) who lived from the 3rd century to the beginning of the 4th century.

There are doubts regarding the historical validity of his exploits recorded in the Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki as well as genealogical accounts of his connection to the Kesshi-Hachidai (eight undocumented emperors); however, there are still many who consider him to be the king (Yamato Sovereignty) who lived from the third century to the beginning of the fourth century.
sen.cmt: Kesshi-Hachidai としました。数字をスペルアウトしました。

sen.j: 『古事記』は崇神天皇の没年を干支により戊寅年と記載しているので（崩年干支または没年干支という）、これを信用して318年（または258年）没と推測する説も中には見られる。
sen.e: As "Kojiki" states that Emperor Sujin died in a year of the Yang Earth Tiger according to the sexagenary cycle, there are theories that estimate the year of his death at 318AD (or 258AD).
As the Kojiki states, Emperor Sujin died in the year of the Yang Earth Tiger, according to the sexagenary cycle. There are theories that estimate the year of his death at 318AD (or 258AD).
Based on a description in the Kojiki that Emperor Sujin died in the year of the Earth-Tiger in the sixty-year Chinese calendar cycle, some people believe that he died in 318 A.D. (or 258 A.D.).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 後述の諡号から、崇神天皇をもって初代天皇とする説や崇神天皇と神武天皇を同一人物と見る説がある。
sen.e: The posthumous name described below has led to theories that that Emperor Sujin was the first emperor of Japan as well as theories that he was the same individual as Emperor Jinmu.
The posthumous name described below has led to theories that Emperor Sujin was the first emperor of Japan, as well as theories that he was the same individual as Emperor Jimmu.
The posthumous name described below has led to theories that Emperor Sujin was the first emperor of Japan, as well as theories that he was the same individual as Emperor Jinmu.

sen.j: 欠史八代を史実の反映と見る立場からは、書紀の記述によると、神武天皇が畿内で即位後は畿内周辺の狭い領域のことしか出てこないが、崇神天皇の代になって初めて、日本の広範囲の出来事の記述が出てくるので、神武天皇から開化天皇までは畿内の地方政権の域を出ず、崇神天皇の代になって初めて日本全国規模の政権になったのではと考える説もある。
sen.e: The theory that he represents historical evidence of the Kesshi Hachidai comes from "Nihon Shoki" in which only very few details were recorded pertaining to the areas surrounding the Kikni region after Emperor Jinmu was enthroned in the area but descriptions came to be entered for events throughout Japan beginning with the enthronement of Emperor Sujin, so it is thought that the power which was restricted to the Kinki region from the times of Emperor Jinmu to Emperor Kaika spread to the whole of Japan following Emperor Sujin.

The theory that he represents historical evidence of the Kesshi Hachidai comes from the Nihon Shoki in which only very few details were recorded pertaining to the areas surrounding the Kikni region, after Emperor Jinmu was enthroned in the area. However, descriptions came to be entered for events throughout Japan beginning with the enthronement of Emperor Sujin, therefore it is believed that the power restricted to the Kinki region from the times of Emperor Jinmu to Emperor Kaika spread to the whole of Japan following Emperor Sujin.

Descriptions in the Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki after the enthronement of Emperor Jinmu are limited to the Kinai region (region around Kyoto and Nara) and its surrounding areas until Emperor Sujin, after whose enthronement descriptions of events in various other areas in Japan appear. Based on these descriptions, some of those who regard the eight undocumented generations of emperors as genuine historical figures argue that the ancient Yamato government was a local power during the period between Emperor Jinmu and Emperor Kaika and established its power nationwide only in the generation of Emperor Sujin.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: また、欠史八代の葛城王朝から崇神天皇に始まる三輪王朝への王朝交替説もある。
sen.e: There is also the theory of the rise and fall of successive dynasties from the Katsuragi Dynasty of the Kesshi Hachidai to the Miwa Dynasty beginning with Emperor Sujin.
There is also the theory of the rise and fall of successive dynasties from the Katsuragi Dynasty of the Kesshi Hachidai to the Miwa Dynasty beginning with Emperor Sujin.
There is also the theory of the rise and fall of successive dynasties from the Katsuragi Dynasty of the Kesshi-Hachidai to the Miwa Dynasty beginning with Emperor Sujin.

sen.j: いずれの説も崇神天皇を実在の人物としている点では共通している。
sen.e: Each of these theories considers Emperor Sujin to have actually existed.
Each of these theories considers Emperor Sujin to have actually existed.
Each of these theories considers Emperor Sujin to have actually existed.

tit.cmt: 小タイトル用に変更しました。

sen.j: 御眞木入日子印恵命（みまきいりひこいにえのみこと） - 『古事記』
sen.e: Mimakiirihikoinie no Mikoto: "Kojiki"

sen.j: 御間城入彦五十瓊殖天皇（みまきいりびこいにえのすめらみこと） - 『日本書紀』
sen.e: Mimakiiribikoinie no Sumera Mikoto: "Nihon Shoki"
Mimakiiribikoinie no Sumera Mikoto: Nihon Shoki

sen.j: 御肇國天皇（はつくにしらすすめらみこと） - 『日本書紀』
sen.e: Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto: "Nihon Shoki"
Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto: Nihon Shoki

sen.j: 美萬貴天皇（みまきのすめらみこと） - 『常陸国風土記』
sen.e: Mimaki no Sumera Mikoto: "Hitachi no Kuni Fudoki"
Mimaki no Sumera Mikoto: Hitachi no Kuni Fudoki
Mimaki no Sumera Mikoto: Hitachi no Kuni Fudoki (the topography of Hitachi Province)
sen.cmt: 常陸国風土記の補足を追加しました。

sen.j: ハツクニシラススメラミコトとの称は、神武天皇（『日本書紀』では始馭天下之天皇はつくにしらすすめらみこと）にも贈られており、初めて天下を治めた天皇という意味であるが、初めて国を治める天皇がふたり存在することになる。
sen.e: The name Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto was also conferred upon Emperor Jinmu (who's name is given as Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto in "Nihon no Shoki" but written using different characters) and originally had the meaning of an emperor who governed the entire country but this indicates that there were two emperors who first ruled the country.

The name Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto was also conferred upon Emperor Jimmu (who's name is given as Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto in the Nihon no Shoki but written using different characters). It originally had the meaning of an emperor who governed the entire country, however, this indicates that there were two emperors who first ruled the country.

The name Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto was also conferred upon Emperor Jinmu (whose name is given as Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto in the Nihon Shoki but written using different characters); it originally had the meaning of an emperor who governed the entire country, however, this indicates that there were two emperors who first ruled the country.
sen.cmt: whose としました。Jinmu としました。

sen.j: これについては、神武の称号にみえる「天下」という抽象的な語は、崇神の称号にみえる国という具体的な語より上位の観念であり、また、後に出来た新しい観念でもあるので、神武は崇神より後に「帝紀」「旧辞」の編者らによって創られたと考えられる。
sen.e: The abstract word for 'the world' that appears in Emperor Jinmu's name indicates a position of greater superiority than the definite word 'country' that appears in Emperor Sujin's name, but this was also a newer concept that developed later, and Emperor Jinmu is believed to have been invented after Emperor Sujin by those who compiled "Teiki" and "Kyuji".

The abstract word for 'the world' that appears in Emperor Jimmu's name indicates a position of greater superiority than the definite word 'country' that appears in Emperor Sujin's name. However, this was also a newer concept that developed later, and Emperor Jinmu is believed to have been invented after Emperor Sujin, by those who compiled the Teiki and the Kyuji.

"Tenka," an abstract word meaning "the world" that appears in Emperor Jinmu's title, is a concept broader in meaning than the word "kuni" (meaning a specific region) that appears in Emperor Sujin's title, and was also created later than the latter, which leads us to believe that Emperor Jinmu is a literary creation made later than Emperor Sujin by those who compiled the Teiki (Imperial Genealogy) and the Kyuji (Court Records).
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: それ故に国（大和）を初めて治められたのは崇神であると考えられる。
sen.e: It is for this reason that Emperor Sujin is thought to be the first to have ruled over the country (Yamato).
It is for this reason that Emperor Sujin is thought to be the first to have ruled over the country (Yamato).
It is for this reason that Emperor Sujin is thought to be the first to have ruled over the country (Yamato).

sen.j: 『常陸風土記』にも「初國所知美麻貴天皇」とある。
sen.e: "Hitachi no Kuni Fudoki" also refers to Emperor Sujin as 'Hatsukuni Shirasumiki no Sumera Mikoto).
The Hitachi no Kuni Fudoki also refers to Emperor Sujin as Hatsukuni Shirasumiki no Sumera Mikoto.
The Hitachi no Kuni Fudoki also refers to Emperor Sujin as Hatsukuni Shirasumiki no Sumera Mikoto.

sen.j: 崇神の和風諡号は「ミマキイリヒコ」、次の垂仁天皇の和風諡号は「イクメイリヒコ」で、共にイリヒコが共通している。
sen.e: Emperor Sujin was posthumously named 'Mimakiirihiko' and his successor, Emperor Suinin, was posthumously named 'Ikumeirihiko', with both referred to as 'Irihiko'.
Emperor Sujin was posthumously named Mimakiirihiko and his successor, Emperor Suinin, was posthumously named Ikumeirihiko, with both referred to as Irihiko.
Emperor Sujin was posthumously named Mimakiirihiko and his successor, Emperor Suinin, was posthumously named Ikumeirihiko, with both referred to as Irihiko.

sen.j: イリヒコ・イリヒメは当時の大王・王族名に現れる特定呼称である。
sen.e: Irihiko and Irihime were specific titles that were used by kings and members of the royal family during this period.
Irihiko and Irihime were specific titles that were used by kings and members of the royal family during this period.
Irihiko and Irihime were specific titles that were used by kings and members of the royal family during this period.

sen.j: 「イリ」が後世の創作とは考えにくいことから、これらの大王・王族は実在の可能性が高まり、崇神を始祖とする「イリ王朝」「三輪王朝」説なども提唱されている。
sen.e: As it is difficult to believe that 'iri' was a later creation, this increases the likelihood that these kings and royals really existed and advocates the theory that Emperor Sujin was the progenitor of the Iri Dynasty and Miwa Dynasty.

As it is difficult to believe that 'iri' was a later creation, this increases the likelihood that these kings and royals really existed and advocates the theory that Emperor Sujin was the progenitor of the Iri and Miwa Dynasties.

As it is difficult to believe that 'iri' was a later creation, this increases the likelihood that these kings and royals really existed and advocates the theory that Emperor Sujin was the progenitor of the Iri and Miwa Dynasties.

sen.j: 崇神・垂仁の二帝の名は和風諡号ではなく実名（諱）をそのまま記紀に記載した、とする説も存在しており、「イリ王朝」が古代日本史に於いて、如何に特殊かつ重要な存在であったかを伺わせる。
sen.e: The theory that Emperor Sujin and Emperor Suinin were recorded in "Kojiki" and "Nihon Shoki" not under their posthumous names but under their real names indicates how important the Iri Dynasty was in ancient Japan.

The theory that Emperor Sujin and Emperor Suinin were recorded in the Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki not under their posthumous names but under their real names indicates how important the Iri Dynasty was in ancient Japan.

The theory that Emperor Sujin and Emperor Suinin were recorded in the Kojiki and the Nihon Shoki not under their posthumous names but under their real names indicates how unique and important the Iri Dynasty was in ancient Japan.
sen.cmt: 一部翻訳を補足しました。

tit.cmt: 小タイトル用に変更しました。

sen.j: 都は磯城瑞籬宮（しきのみずかきのみや、奈良県桜井市金屋の志貴御県坐神社が伝承地）。
sen.e: The imperial capital was based around Shikino Mizukaki Palace (now Shikinomi agataniimasu-jinja Shrine in Kanaya, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture).
The imperial capital was based around Shikino Mizukaki Palace (now Shikinomi agataniimasu-jinja Shrine in Kanaya, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture).
The imperial capital was based around Shikino Mizukaki Palace (now Shikinomi agataniimasu-jinja Shrine in Kanaya, Sakurai City, Nara Prefecture).

sen.j: 『古事記』には、「師木の水垣宮（みづかきのみや）に坐しまして、天の下治めらしめしき」とある。
sen.e: "Kojiki" states that 'the emperor resided at Mizukaki Palace in Shiki from where governed the entire nation'.
The Kojiki states that 'the emperor resided at Mizukaki Palace in Shiki from where he governed the entire nation.'
It is written in the Kojiki that "the emperor ruled the nation at Mizukaki Palace in Shiki."
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 年代は『日本書紀』の編年に従って便宜を図った。
sen.e: For convenience, dates are given according to the chronology of "Nihon Shoki".
For convenience, dates are given according to the chronology of the Nihon Shoki.
For convenience, dates are given according to the chronology of the Nihon Shoki.

sen.j: 開化天皇10年（紀元前148年）に産まれ、28年（紀元前130年）に立太子、60年（紀元前98年）の開化天皇崩御に伴い翌年即位。
sen.e: Born in the 10th year of the reign of Emperor Kaika (148BC) and pronounced crown prince in 130 BC before being enthroned as emperor in 99BC, the year following the death of Emperor Kaika.
He was born in the 10th year of the reign of Emperor Kaika (148BC) and pronounced crown prince in 130 BC before being enthroned as emperor in 99BC, the year following the death of Emperor Kaika.

He was born in the tenth year of the reign of Emperor Kaika (148 B.C.) and pronounced crown prince in 130 B.C. before being enthroned as emperor, the year following the death of Emperor Kaika (98 B.C.).

sen.j: 崇神天皇3年（紀元前95年）9月、三輪山西麓の瑞籬宮（みずかきのみや）に遷都。
sen.e: 95BC, ninth month: The capital was relocated to Mizukaki Palace on the western foot of Mt. Miwa.
In the ninth month of 95BC, the capital was relocated to Mizukaki Palace on the western foot of Mt. Miwa.
In the ninth month of 95 B.C., the capital was relocated to Mizukaki Palace on the western foot of Mt. Miwa.

sen.j: 崇神天皇5年（紀元前93年）、疫病が流行り、多くの人民が死に絶えた。
sen.e: 93BC: A great plague spread across Japan and killed many people.
In 93BC, a great plague spread across Japan and killed many people.
In 93 B.C., a great plague spread across Japan and killed many people.

sen.j: 崇神天皇6年（紀元前92年）、疫病を鎮めるべく、従来宮中に祀られていた天照大神と倭大国魂神（大和大国魂神）を皇居の外に移した。
sen.e: 92BC: Amaterasu Omikami and Yamato no Okunitama no Kami (Yamato Okunitama no Okami), which until then were enshrined within the imperial palace were moved outside in order to suppress the plague.
In 92BC, Amaterasu Omikami and Yamato no Okunitama no Kami (Yamato Okunitama no Okami), which until then were enshrined within the imperial palace were moved outside in order to suppress the plague.
In 92 B.C., Amaterasu Omikami and Yamato no Okunitama no Kami, which until then were enshrined within the imperial palace were moved outside in order to suppress the plague.

sen.j: 天照大神を豊鍬入姫命に託し、笠縫邑（現在の檜原神社）に祀らせ、その後各地を移動したが、垂仁天皇25年（紀元前5年）に現在の伊勢神宮内宮に御鎮座した。
sen.e: Princess Toyosuki Iribime no Mikoto received an oracle from Amaterasu Omikami and was charged with venerating the goddess at Kasanui Village (in what is now Omiwa-jinja Shrine) but Amaterasu Omikami was subsequently moved throughout the country before being enshrined in the naiku (inner shrine) of Ise-jingu Shrine in 5AD.

Princess Toyosuki Iribime no Mikoto received a prophesy from Amaterasu Omikami and was charged with venerating the goddess at Kasanui Village (in what is now Omiwa-jinja Shrine) but Amaterasu Omikami was subsequently moved throughout the country before being enshrined in the naiku (inner shrine) of Ise-jingu Shrine in 5AD.

Princess Toyosuki Iribime no Mikoto was charged with venerating Amaterasu Omikami at Kasanui Village (in what is now Hibara-jinja Shrine); Amaterasu Omikami was subsequently moved throughout the country before being enshrined in the naiku (inner shrine) of Ise-jingu Shrine in 5 B.C.
sen.cmt: 翻訳を原文に沿って修正しました。

sen.j: （詳細記事：元伊勢）
sen.e: Refer to the article 'Motoise' for more details.
Refer to the article 'Motoise' for more details.
Refer to the article 'Motoise' for more details.

sen.j: 倭大国魂神を渟名城入媛命に託し、長岡岬に祀らせたが（現在の大和神社の初め）、媛は身体が痩せ細って祀ることが出来なかった。
sen.e: Nunakiiribime no Mikoto received an oracle from Yamato Okunitama no Okami and was charged with venerating him in Nagaoka no Saki (the origin of what is now Oyamato-jinja Shrine) but she became emaciated and unable to worship.

Nunakiiribime no Mikoto received an oracle from Yamato Okunitama no Okami and was charged with venerating him in Nagaoka no Saki (the origin of what is now Oyamato-jinja Shrine) but she became emaciated and unable to worship.

Princess Nunakiiribime no Mikoto was charged with venerating Yamato no Okunitama no Kami in Nagaoka no Saki (the origin of what is now Oyamato-jinja Shrine) but she became emaciated and unable to worship.
sen.cmt: 翻訳を原文に沿って修正しました。

sen.j: 崇神天皇7年（紀元前91年）2月、大物主神、倭迹迹日百襲姫命に乗り移り託宣する。
sen.e: 91BC, second month: Omononushi transferred to Princess Yamatototobimomoso Hime no Mikoto and spoke.
In the second month of 91BC, Omononushi possessed Princess Yamatototobimomoso Hime no Mikoto and spoke.
In the second month of 91 B.C., Princess Yamatotobimomoso Hime no Mikoto was possessed by a god named Omononushi, who gave oracles.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 11月、大田田根子（大物主神の子とも子孫ともいう）を大物主神を祭る神主とし（これは現在の大神神社に相当し、三輪山を御神体としている）、市磯長尾市（いちしのながおち）を倭大国魂神を祭る神主としたところ、疫病は終息し、五穀豊穣となる。
sen.e: Eleventh month: When Otataneko (said to be either the child or descendant of Omononushi) was made a Shinto priest (at what is now Omiwa-jinja Shrine which serves Mt. Miwa as a sacret object) for the worship of Omononushi and Ichishi no Nagaochi was made a Shinto priest for the worship of Yamato Okunitama no Okami, the plague ended and an abundant harvest was reaped.

In the eleventh month, the plague ended and an abundant harvest ensued when Otataneko (said to be either the child or descendant of Omononushi) was made a Shinto priest (at what is now Omiwa-jinja Shrine, which has made Mt. Miwa sacred) for the worship of Omononushi and Ichishi no Nagaochi was made a Shinto priest for the worship of Yamato Okunitama no Okami.

In the eleventh month, the plague ended and an abundant harvest ensued when Taneko OTA (believed to be a child or descendant of Omononushi) was appointed as the priest to perform religious rituals for Omononushi (at present-day Omiwa Shrine, which worships Mt. Miwa as its sacred deity) and Ichishi no Nagaochi as the priest for a Shinto god named Yamato no Okunitama no Kami.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: 崇神天皇10年（紀元前88年）9月、大彦命を北陸道に、武渟川別を東海道に、吉備津彦命を山陽道に、丹波道主命を丹波国（山陰道）に将軍として遣わし、従わないものを討伐させた（四道将軍）。
sen.e: 88BC, ninth month: Obiko no Mikoto was dispatched to Hokurikudo (northwestern edge of Honshu), Takenunakawawake to Tokaido (southeastern edge of Honshu), Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto to Sanyodo (southwestern edge of Honshu) and Tanba no Michi no Ushi no Mikoto to Tanba Province (Sanindo), where they served as shogun (known as the 'Shido Shogun' or 'Four Shogun') and ordered to subjugate all who did not obey.

In the ninth month of 88BC, Obiko no Mikoto was dispatched to Hokurikudo (northwestern edge of Honshu), Takenunakawawake to Tokaido (southeastern edge of Honshu), Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto to Sanyodo (southwestern edge of Honshu) and Tanba no Michi no Ushi no Mikoto to Tanba Province (Sanindo), where they served as shogun (known as the 'Shido Shogun' or 'Four Shogun') and ordered to subjugate all who did not obey.

In the ninth month of 88 B.C., Emperor Sujin dispatched Obiko no Mikoto to Hokurikudo (northwestern edge of Honshu), Takenuna KAWAWAKE to Tokaido (southeastern edge of Honshu), Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto to Sanyodo (southwestern edge of Honshu) and Tanbamichi nushi no Mikoto to Tanba Province (Sanindo) as General Commanders (known as the "Four Shogun") in order to conquer those who did not obey his orders.
sen.cmt: FBに基づいて修正しました。

sen.j: しかし、大彦命だけは異変を察知して和珥坂（わにのさか、奈良県天理市）から引き返し、倭迹迹日百襲姫命の予言から武埴安彦（たけはにやすびこ、孝元天皇の皇子）の叛意を知ることとなる。
sen.e: However, Obuiko no Mikoto encountered a strange occurrence and returned from Wani no Saka (Tenri City, Nara Prefecture), an event which led him to become aware from Princess Yamatototobimomoso Hime no Mikoto's prediction that Takehaniyasubiko (the son of Emperor Kogen) was plotting an act of treason.

However, Obuiko no Mikoto encountered a strange occurrence and returned from Wani no Saka (Tenri City, Nara Prefecture), an event which led him to become aware of the prediction made by Princess Yamatototobimomoso Hime no Mikoto that Takehaniyasubiko (the son of Emperor Kogen) was plotting an act of treason.

However, Obiko no Mikoto encountered a strange occurrence and returned from Wani no Saka (Tenri City, Nara Prefecture), an event which led him to become aware of the prediction made by Princess Yamatototobimomoso Hime no Mikoto that Takehani Yasubiko (the son of Emperor Kogen) was plotting an act of treason.
sen.cmt: 人名を一部修正しました。

sen.j: 武埴安彦は山背国から、その妻吾田媛は大坂からともに都を襲撃しようとしたが、天皇は五十狭芹彦命（吉備津彦命）の軍を遣わして吾田媛勢を迎え討ち、一方の安彦勢には、大彦命と彦国葺（ひこくにぶく、和珥氏の祖）を差し向かわせ、これを打ち破った。
sen.e: Takehani Yasubiko attempted to attack the capital from Yamashiro Province while his wife, Princess Atahime attempted to attack from Osaka but the emperor dispatched the forces of Hiko Isaseribiko no Mikoto (Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto) to attack Princess Atahime's army while Obime no Mikoto and Hikokunibuku (an ancestor of the Wani clan) attacked Yasubiko's forces

Takehani Yasubiko attempted to attack the capital from Yamashiro Province while his wife, Princess Atahime attempted to attack from Osaka but the emperor dispatched the forces of Hiko Isaseribiko no Mikoto (Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto) to attack Princess Atahime's army while Obime no Mikoto and Hikokunibuku (an ancestor of the Wani clan) attacked Yasubiko's forces.

Takehani Yasubiko attempted to attack the capital from Yamashiro Province while his wife, Princess Atahime attempted to attack from Osaka but the emperor dispatched the forces of Hiko Isaseribiko no Mikoto (Kibitsuhiko no Mikoto) to attack Princess Atahime's army while Obiko no Mikoto and Hikokunibuku (an ancestor of the Wani clan) attacked Yasubiko's forces.
sen.cmt: 人名を一部修正しました。

sen.j: 10月、畿内は平穏となり、四道将軍が再び出発。
sen.e: Tenth month: Peace was achieved within the Kinki region and the Shido Shogun once again left for their posts.
In the tenth month, peace was achieved within the Kinki region and the Shido Shogun once again left for their posts.
In the tenth month, peace was achieved within the Kinai region and the Shido Shogun once again left for their posts.

sen.j: 崇神天皇11年（紀元前87年）4月、四道将軍が地方の賊軍を平定させて帰参、その様を奏上した。
sen.e: 87BC, fourth month: The Shido Shogun reported the suppression of rebels to the emperor.
In the fourth month of 87BC, the Shido Shogun reported the suppression of rebels to the emperor.
In the fourth month of 87 B.C., the Shido Shogun reported the suppression of rebels to the emperor.

sen.j: 崇神天皇12年（紀元前86年）9月、戸口を調査し、課役を科す。
sen.e: 86BC, ninth month: The first survey of the population began and citizens were given their assignments.
In the ninth month of 86BC, the first survey of the population began and citizens were given their assignments.
In the ninth month of 86 B.C., the first survey of the population began and citizens were given their assignments.

sen.j: 天下平穏となり、天皇は御肇国天皇と褒め称えられる。
sen.e: The nation was at peace and the emperor was praised as Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto.
The nation was at peace and the emperor was praised as Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto.
The nation was at peace and the emperor was praised as Hatsukunishirasu Sumera Mikoto.

sen.j: 崇神天皇48年（紀元前50年）1月、豊城命（豊城入彦命）と活目命（垂仁天皇）を呼び、どちらを皇太子にするかについて熟慮決断した。
sen.e: 50BC, first month: The emperor summoned Toyoki no Mikoto and Ikume no Mikoto (Emperor Suinin) to decide which of the two would be made crown prince.
In the first month of 50BC, the emperor summoned Toyoki no Mikoto and Ikume no Mikoto (Emperor Suinin) to decide which of the two would be made crown prince.
In the first month of 50 B.C., the emperor summoned Toyoki no Mikoto and Ikume no Mikoto (Emperor Suinin) to decide which of the two would be made crown prince.

sen.j: 4月、弟の活目命を皇太子とし、豊城命に東国を治めさせた。
sen.e: Fourth month: The emperor's younger brother, Ikume no Mikoto, was named as crown prince and Toyoki no Mikoto was ordered to subdue the east of the country.
In the fourth month, the emperor's younger brother, Ikume no Mikoto, was named as crown prince and Toyoki no Mikoto was ordered to subdue the east of the country.
In the fourth month, the emperor's younger brother, Ikume no Mikoto, was named as crown prince and Toyoki no Mikoto was ordered to subdue the east of the country.

sen.j: 崇神天皇60年（紀元前38年）7月、飯入根（いいいりね）が出雲大社の神宝を献上。
sen.e: 38BC, seventh month: Iiirine presented the sacred treasure of Izumo Taisha Shrine to the emperor.
In the seventh month of 38BC, Iiirine presented the sacred treasure of Izumo Taisha Shrine to the emperor.
In the seventh month of 38 B.C., Iiirine presented the sacred treasure of Izumo Taisha Shrine to the emperor.

sen.j: 兄の出雲振根が飯入根を謀殺するが、朝廷に誅殺される。
sen.e: His brother, Izumo Furune, murdered Iirine but was himself executed by the imperial court.
His brother, Izumo Furune, murdered Iirine but was himself executed by the imperial court.
His older brother, Izumo Furune, murdered Iiirine but was himself executed by the imperial court.
sen.cmt: 人名を一部修正しました。

sen.j: 崇神天皇65年（紀元前33年）7月、任那国が蘇那曷叱知（そなかしち）を遣わして朝貢した。
sen.e: 33BC, seventh month: The Gaya confederacy of southern Korea dispatched Sonakashichi to pay tribute to Japan's imperial court.
In the seventh month of 33BC, the Gaya confederacy of southern Korea dispatched Sonakashichi to pay tribute to Japan's imperial court.
In the seventh month of 33 B.C., Mimana (the Gaya confederacy of southern Korea) dispatched Sonakashichi to pay tribute to Japan's imperial court.

sen.j: 崇神天皇68年（紀元前30年）12月、120歳で崩御（『古事記』は、戊寅年12月崩御、168歳とする）。
sen.e: 30BC, twelfth month: The emperor died aged 120 ("Kojiki" states that he died aged 168 years in the twelfth month 18AD).
In the twelfth month 30BC, the emperor died aged at 120 (the Kojiki states that he died aged 168 years in the twelfth month 18AD).
In the twelfth month 30 B.C., the emperor died at the age 120 (the Kojiki states that he died at the age 168 in the twelfth month of the year of the Yang Earth Tiger).
sen.cmt: 原文どおりに戊寅年12月崩御 としました。

sen.j: 『古事記』には、天下を統一して、平和で人民が豊かで幸せに暮らすことが出来るようになり、その御世を称えて初めて国を治めた御真木天皇「所知初国之御真木天皇」と謂う、とある。
sen.e: "Kojiki" records that Emperor Sujin united the country, brought peace, prosperity and happiness to the people, and was the first to be praised as Mimakono Sumera Mikoto (Hatsukunishirashishi Mimakinosumera Mikoto) for governing the country.

The Kojiki records that Emperor Sujin united the country, brought peace, prosperity and happiness to the people, and was the first to be praised as Mimakono Sumera Mikoto (Hatsukunishirashishi Mimakinosumera Mikoto) for governing the country.

The Kojiki records that Emperor Sujin united the country, brought peace, prosperity and happiness to the people, and was the first to be praised as Mimakono Sumera Mikoto (Hatsukunishirashishi Mimakinosumera Mikoto) for governing the country.

sen.j: また、依網池（よさみのいけ、大阪市住吉区）や軽（奈良県高市郡）の酒折（さかをり）池などの池溝を開いて、大いに農業の便を図ったと伝えられる。
sen.e: In addition, he is was responsible for the digging of lakes such as Yosami-no-Ike (Sumiyoshi Ward, Osaka Prefecture) and Sakawori-no-Ike in Karu (Takaichi County, Nara Prefecture), and is reputed to have made numerous contributions to agriculture.

In addition, he was responsible for the digging of lakes such as Yosami-no-Ike (Sumiyoshi Ward, Osaka Prefecture) and Sakawori-no-Ike in Karu (Takaichi County, Nara Prefecture), and is reputed to have made numerous contributions to agriculture.

In addition, he was responsible for the digging of ponds such as Yosami-no-Ike Pond (Sumiyoshi Ward, Osaka Prefecture) and Sakawori-no-Ike Pond in Karu (Takaichi-gun, Nara Prefecture), and is reputed to have made numerous contributions to agriculture.

tit.cmt: 左記のようにしました。

sen.j: 山邊道勾岡上陵（やまのべのみちのまがりのおかのえのみささぎ）に葬られた。
sen.e: He was buried in Yamanobenomichi no Magari no oka no e no Misasagi.
He was buried in Yamanobenomichi no Magari no oka no e no Misasagi.
He was buried in Yamanobenomichi no Magari no oka no e no Misasagi.

sen.j: 『古事記』に「山邊道勾（まがり）之岡上」。
sen.e: "Kojiki" gives his burial place as 'Yamanobenomichi no Magari no oka no e'.
The Kojiki gives his burial place as 'Yamanobenomichi no Magari no oka no e.'
The Kojiki gives his burial place as 'Yamanobenomichi no Magari no oka no e.'

sen.j: 現在、同陵は奈良県天理市柳本町の柳本行燈山古墳（前方後円墳・全長242m）に比定される。
sen.e: This tomb is believed to be the Yanagimoto Andon-yama Tomb (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound of 242 m in length) in modern-day Yanagimoto-cho, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.
This tomb is believed to be the Yanagimoto Andon-yama Tomb (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound of 242 m in length) in modern-day Yanagimoto-cho, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.
This tomb is believed to be the Yanagimoto Andon-yama Tomb (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound of 242 m in length) in modern-day Yanagimoto-cho, Tenri City, Nara Prefecture.

sen.j: しかしながら、それより少し前に造られた西殿塚古墳（前方後円墳・全長220m）を、その真陵とする考え方もある。
sen.e: However, there is also the opinion that Nishitonotsuka Tomb (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound of 220 m in length) constructed slightly in front of this is the actual tomb.
However, there is also the opinion that Nishitonotsuka Tomb (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound of 220 m in length) constructed slightly in front of this is the actual tomb.
However, there is also the opinion that Nishitonotsuka Tomb (large keyhole-shaped tomb mound of 220 m in length) constructed in a slightly earlier time is the actual tomb.
sen.cmt: 翻訳を一部修正しました。

sen.j: 行燈山古墳は、形状が帆立貝形古墳（初期の前方後円墳。
sen.e: Andon-yama Tomb is a keyhole-shaped tumulus (early keyhole-shaped tomb mound.
Andon-yama Tomb is a keyhole-shaped tumulus (early keyhole-shaped tomb mound.
Andon-yama Tomb is a scallop shaped tomb (early keyhole-shaped tomb mound;

sen.j: 前方部が小さく造られている）のようになっているが、これは江戸時代の改修工事によるものとも言われている。
sen.e: These have one square end and one circular end when looked down upon from above) but this is said to have been formed during repairs that were mad during the Edo period.
These have one square end and one circular end when looked down upon from above) but this is said to have been formed during repairs that were made during the Edo period.
the square front part is made smaller than the ones made in later times) but this is said to have been formed during repairs that were made during the Edo period.
sen.cmt: 「前方部が小さく造られている」 の意味に修正しました。
